user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of lfs_fs_gc:
```c
int lfs_fs_gc(lfs_t *lfs) {
    int err = LFS_LOCK(lfs->cfg);
    if (err) {
        return err;
    }
    LFS_TRACE("lfs_fs_gc(%p)", (void*)lfs);

    err = lfs_fs_gc_(lfs);

    LFS_TRACE("lfs_fs_gc -> %d", err);
    LFS_UNLOCK(lfs->cfg);
    return err;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function lfs_fs_gc:
#define LFS_LOCK(cfg) ((void)cfg,0)
...
#define LFS_UNLOCK(cfg) ((void)cfg)
...
#define LFS_TRACE(__VA_ARGS__) 
...
static int lfs_fs_gc_(lfs_t *lfs) {
    // force consistency, even if we're not necessarily going to write,
    // because this function is supposed to take care of janitorial work
    // isn't it?
    int err = lfs_fs_forceconsistency(lfs);
    if (err) {
        return err;
    }

    // try to compact metadata pairs, note we can't really accomplish
    // anything if compact_thresh doesn't at least leave a prog_size
    // available
    if (lfs->cfg->compact_thresh
            < lfs->cfg->block_size - lfs->cfg->prog_size) {
        // iterate over all mdirs
        lfs_mdir_t mdir = {.tail = {0, 1}};
        while (!lfs_pair_isnull(mdir.tail)) {
            err = lfs_dir_fetch(lfs, &mdir, mdir.tail);
            if (err) {
                return err;
            }

            // not erased? exceeds our compaction threshold?
            if (!mdir.erased || ((lfs->cfg->compact_thresh == 0)
                    ? mdir.off > lfs->cfg->block_size - lfs->cfg->block_size/8
                    : mdir.off > lfs->cfg->compact_thresh)) {
                // the easiest way to trigger a compaction is to mark
                // the mdir as unerased and add an empty commit
                mdir.erased = false;
                err = lfs_dir_commit(lfs, &mdir, NULL, 0);
                if (err) {
                    return err;
                }
            }
        }
    }

    // try to populate the lookahead buffer, unless it's already full
    if (lfs->lookahead.size < 8*lfs->cfg->lookahead_size) {
        err = lfs_alloc_scan(lfs);
        if (err) {
            return err;
        }
    }

    return 0;
}
...
typedef struct lfs {
    lfs_cache_t rcache;
    lfs_cache_t pcache;

    lfs_block_t root[2];
    struct lfs_mlist {
        struct lfs_mlist *next;
        uint16_t id;
        uint8_t type;
        lfs_mdir_t m;
    } *mlist;
    uint32_t seed;

    lfs_gstate_t gstate;
    lfs_gstate_t gdisk;
    lfs_gstate_t gdelta;

    struct lfs_lookahead {
        lfs_block_t start;
        lfs_block_t size;
        lfs_block_t next;
        lfs_block_t ckpoint;
        uint8_t *buffer;
    } lookahead;

    const struct lfs_config *cfg;
    lfs_size_t block_count;
    lfs_size_t name_max;
    lfs_size_t file_max;
    lfs_size_t attr_max;
    lfs_size_t inline_max;

#ifdef LFS_MIGRATE
    struct lfs1 *lfs1;
#endif
} lfs_t
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No code fragments in the provided functions modify the function parameter pointer itself. Specifically:
- There are no assignments to the parameter variable (no occurrences like "lfs = ...", "lfs++", or "lfs += ...") in lfs_fs_gc or lfs_fs_gc_.
- All uses of lfs access or modify the object it points to (e.g., lfs->cfg, lfs->lookahead, setting fields via functions called with lfs), which is permitted by Rule 17.8 (the object pointed to may be modified).
- The LFS_LOCK and LFS_UNLOCK macros, as defined, do not modify their argument (they evaluate ((void)cfg,0) and ((void)cfg) respectively), so the macro calls LFS_LOCK(lfs->cfg) and LFS_UNLOCK(lfs->cfg) do not modify the pointer parameter lfs nor lfs->cfg itself.
- LFS_TRACE uses a cast (void*)lfs and an empty macro body in the provided definition, so it does not modify the parameter.
- Local variables (e.g., mdir) are modified, and functions called with lfs (e.g., lfs_dir_fetch, lfs_dir_commit, lfs_alloc_scan) may modify the object pointed to by lfs, which is allowed; such calls do not reassign the parameter variable inside the analyzed functions.

Because none of the code in the provided fragments assigns to or otherwise modifies the pointer parameter itself, there are no violations of MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 to report from these snippets.
